At what point are we going to stop imagining that the problem is with individual "officers who harbor racial animosities?"

At what point will we demand that all institutions of policing be demolished, re-imagined and rebuilt?

At what point will people come to realize that in no way could so many individual police officers somehow operate as "rogues" without at least the tacit encouragement and support of their departments?

At what point will we come to grips with the fact that our police culture runs on fear and control? And that it so very obviously includes the right of police officers to render a preliminary verdict and dole out punishment on the spot?

Or we can keep imagining that all we need is better screening and total surveillance of people who should be respected and trusted public servants. If we want that kind of policing culture--and we sure better--we should have it. If not, we get what we deserve: more lofty rhetoric extolling our obviously corrupt and authoritarian institutions as they intimidate, control, injure and kill us with few consequences.

Black, brown, yellow, red or white.

So now it is San Francisco, the bastion of liberalism. At what point are we going to stop this drip, drip, drip of investigating Police Departments one at a time and assume as the evidence seems to show and minorities have been saying for a very long time, that it is more probable than not (using a term from the deflategate report) that ALL Police Departments in this country are sheltering numerous officers who harbor racial animosities and for the Justice Department to simply go ahead and investigate ALL of them starting now? It may be expensive and time consuming but confidence in the law is the foundation of any society. We are quickly losing that.

it would take a dramatic shift in the foundation of this country's cultural values for this to become commonplace. america, for better or worse, is founded on the belief that if you disagree with something, you should question it, rather than accepting it out of obedience, and that leaves plenty of room for deviation from the norm-an individualist society. the cultural background of these dutiful salon workers is one of conformity and cohesion for the greater good, where the individual and the group must, for the survival of the society, accept its core tenets unquestioningly-a collectivist society. i'm not saying one is better than the other, just that cultural attitudes aren't always interchangeable.

You cannot be serious. Not all young cops are white and most have college......you ARE making gross assumptions about a subject you dont' know about...............there are NO widespread reports of police brutality...there is more black on black crime out there!

Charles Blow's recent column recites surprising FBI statistics that of all racial groups, black cops kill black men more than whites.  We all need to check our inaccurate and sometimes biased thoughts.

Actually, having had four family members in the NYPD for over twenty years I do indeed know what I'm talking about, sorry to have to say. There are no widespread reports of police brutality if your choice source for news is Fox. Otherwise what you see in Baltimore, and Jefferson, and NYC and San Francisco are merely but the highlights. The police are institutionalized racists, though the white majority, in fear , cover for them well.

Given the magnitude and consistency of police brutality toward American citizens, we should,perhaps, better examine and evaluate the criteria being used to hire officers in the first place.

Giving young white males with little education and apparently insufficient "on the job training", along with a firearm is not a recipe for successful law enforcement.
Placing them in police environments where racism has become institutionalized
serves only to perpetuate an untenable social order.

Generalizing can be misleading, but the widespread reports of police brutality across this country are real and for the sake of all need to be addressed. If police are to receive the respect to which they should be entitled, they need to respect the citizens who employ them.

Citizens want "police protection" but they also want justice; and regardless of where they are, the police themselves are not above the laws they try to enforce.

If you do not care if the NSA reads your email and records every phone number you dial and text message you have ever sent, then ok. But are you ok with the fact the NSA has certainly spent BILLIONS of dollars doing this for no value at all? Are you ok with the NSA purposely inserting backdoors into products US corporations buy weakening their ability to keep out hackers and foreign governments ripping off intellectual property? Are you ok with this if at some point in the future someone in the government turns this capability against political opponents to stay in power or enrich themselves or their cronies?

Perhaps you are right that there probably isn't much of interest in the vast majority of data being collected like your email but this is costing a tremendous amount of money for a trivial benefit with the potential to spawn an Orwellian police state. This is an incredibly bad bargain for the American people except for those profiting in the surveillance industrial complex. Be afraid....very afraid.

A nice ending to your beating story, (Mr. "Tim") It's nice when the beater get caught, but your observation that the beater was subjected to the cost of his attorney, and thus was punished, was wishful thinking. It was probably his brother in law.

You should have sued the guy yourself for your obvious PTSD. You really owe it to society, and yourself, to really get into the guys pocket and make him pay up. We all get angry, but after the age of three or so the normal person is able to put the brakes on. This guy needed a hard lesson, because the next person he attacks could get seriously injured. A bully needs a comeuppance .

Peter, I wish I could click "agree" a hundred times. Not only could and should the guy have been successfully sued, but even if his quarry didn't want the ordeal, a skillful lawyer (or any semicompetent one) could have filed the open-and-shut complaint, made the guy's life hell till he settled. He was over a barrel, exactly where he deserved to be.

That said, Tim, the main thing is you appear to have gotten over it and moved on, so you seem to have responded to this heinous thing ok. But this type of situation is what the legal (criminal and civil) system is in place for.

I was beaten up in the Metro here in 2009 by a big white guy (I'm white too), who apparently didn't like the idea that I might get on the train before he did. I don't really know why he did it - there was no reason for him to sucker punch me and then beat me continuously for about 30 seconds straight (that may not sound very long but it was a lot of punches). He only stopped when his girlfriend yelled his name, and they both got onto the train. No one else did or said anything and, in fact, the train sat there the whole time until they got on. Fortunately, I had covered my face and only had a busted lip and some bruises, though I often think it could have been a lot worse. I filed a police report with a skeptical transit officer that same day. Three months later, I had the pleasure of pointing out my attacker to that same officer during a police training exercise at the Metro station. The attacker wasn't too smart and turned out to be a regular commuter there. In any event, I couldn't believe how satisfying it was to stand to the side and see that thug get arrested. I was more traumatized than I realized, but that arrest really helped me move on. He was charged but was later allowed to have the charges dropped if he stayed out of trouble for 9 months. That was punishment enough for me. I'm sure it cost a pretty penny to get an attorney for all of that. I understand and empathize with the emotional struggles of Mr. Clarke and others with similar stories.
